Homage to Bodhisattva Jeweled Moon I take refuge in these and other innumerable and boundless great bodhisattva mahÄsattvas in the worlds of the ten directions.
I respectfully bow to the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and all the sages.

Homage to the pratyekabuddha of straightforward merit, homage to the pratyekabuddha of consciousness, homage to the pratyekabuddha of fragrance, homage to the pratyekabuddha of having fragrance, homage to the pratyekabuddha who sees people flying, homage to the pratyekabuddha Kapila, homage to the pratyekabuddha of the Qin dynasty, homage to the pratyekabuddha Candraprabha, homage to the pratyekabuddha of good wisdom, homage to the pratyekabuddha ÅšÅ«dra. I take refuge in these and other innumerable pratyekabuddhas.
Having paid homage to the Three Jewels, I next repent.

The assembly, now with tranquil body and mind, without deceit and obstruction, at this very time when goodness is born and evil is extinguished, should each give rise to four kinds of contemplations as a preliminary expedient for extinguishing offenses.
What are the four?
First, contemplating causes and conditions;
Second, contemplating the fruits of retribution;
Third, contemplating my own body;
Fourth, contemplating the TathÄgata's body.

The first contemplation of causes and conditions is to know that this offense of mine is due to ignorance and improper thought. I lack the power of right contemplation and do not recognize its faults. I have distanced myself from good friends, Buddhas, and Bodhisattvas, and have followed the path of Mara, walking on treacherous and dangerous paths. It is like a fish swallowing a hook, not knowing its danger. It is like a silkworm spinning a cocoon, binding itself. It is like a moth flying into a fire, burning itself.
Due to these causes and conditions, I am unable to extricate myself.

The second contemplation of karmic retribution is that all evil and unwholesome karma, flowing through the three times, has endless suffering as its fruit. I am drowning in the vast ocean of darkness, to be devoured by the rakshasa of afflictions.

In future lives, birth and death will be obscure and boundless. Even if I were to attain the status of a wheel-turning sage king, ruling the four continents with flying freedom and possessing the seven treasures, after death I would not escape falling into the evil realms.

The rewards of the four formless [realms] are the most honored in the three realms, but when merit is exhausted, one returns to becoming a worm in the head of an ox. How much more so for those with no merit and virtue who are also lazy and do not diligently repent?
This is also like embracing a rock and sinking in the abyss, it is difficult to escape.

Third, contemplate my own body. Although I have the correct cause of the enlightened nature, it is covered by the dark thicket of afflictions, and without the power of the cause of enlightenment, it cannot be revealed.

I should now give rise to a superior mind, break through the heavy obstructions of ignorance and inversion, end the false and suffering causes of birth and death, reveal the great enlightened wisdom of the TathÄgata, and establish the wondrous fruit of unsurpassed nirvÄá¹‡a.

Fourth, contemplate the body of the TathÄgata, which is unconditioned, tranquil, illuminating, free from the four propositions and a hundred negations, endowed with myriad virtues, and eternally abiding.
Although he has expediently entered into nirvÄá¹‡a, he has never for a moment abandoned his compassionate rescue.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Giving rise to such a mind can be called the good ferry for extinguishing offenses and the essential practice for removing hindrances.
For this reason, disciples!
Today, with utmost sincerity, we bow our heads and take refuge in the Buddha.

We take refuge in the Buddha of Radiant Jewel Treasury in the East, the Buddha of Manifesting Accumulated Treasures in the South, the Buddha of Dharma Realm Wisdom Lamp in the West, the Buddha of Supreme Subjugation in the North, the Buddha of Dragon Sovereignty in the Southeast, the Buddha of Turning All Saá¹ƒsÄra in the Southwest, the Buddha of Boundless Wisdom Sovereignty in the Northwest, the Buddha of Boundless Meritorious Virtue Moon in the Northeast, the Buddha of Ocean Wisdom and Spiritual Powers in the Nadir, and the Buddha of All Victories in the Zenith. We take refuge in the Three Jewels in the ten directions and throughout the realm of space.
Disciples!

From beginningless time until today, it has nurtured afflictions that become deeper, thicker, more abundant, and more luxuriant every day, covering the eye of wisdom and preventing it from seeing anything, severing various wholesome [activities] and preventing their continuity, giving rise to hindrances and preventing one from seeing the Buddha, hearing the true Dharma, and encountering the noble Sangha.
The afflictions give rise to hindrances, preventing one from seeing the good and evil karmic activities in all past and future worlds.

The afflictions hinder one from receiving the fruits of human and heavenly nobility. The afflictions hinder one from being born in the form and formless realms and attaining the bliss of dhyÄna concentration. The afflictions hinder one from attaining mastery, spiritual powers, flying, becoming invisible, and
reaching the pure lands of the buddhas in the ten directions to listen to the Dharma. The afflictions hinder one from studying the counting of breaths,
the contemplation of impurity, and other practices. The afflictions hinder one from studying the causes and conditions of loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity.

The afflictions hinder one from studying the seven skillful means and the meaning of the three contemplations. The afflictions hinder one from studying the four establishments of mindfulness, the stage of heat, the stage of summit, and the stage of acquiescence.

The affliction of the obstacle of vexation is the affliction that obstructs learning, contemplation, and cultivation of the first dharma. The affliction of the obstacle of learning the emptiness of equality and the middle wayğŸ”½is the affliction of the obstacle of the characteristics of learning the eightfold correct path. The affliction of the obstacle of not demonstrating the characteristics of learning the seven factors of enlightenment
is the affliction of the obstacle of learning the factors of the path and the contemplation of causes and conditions. The affliction of the obstacle of learning the
eight liberations and the nine kinds of emptiness is the affliction of the obstacle of learning the ten knowledges and samÄdhis. The affliction of the obstacle of learning
the three insights, the six supernormal powers, and the four unobstructed [abilities] is the affliction of the obstacle of learning the six pÄramitÄs and the four immeasurable [minds].

The affliction of the obstacle of learning the four means of conversion and extensively transforming [others] is the affliction of the obstacle of learning the mind of the Great Vehicle and the four great vows. The affliction of the obstacle of learning the ten abidings and the ten practices is the affliction of the obstacle of learning the ten dedications and the ten vows.

The afflictive hindrances of understanding the first, second, third, and fourth grounds, the afflictive hindrances of knowledge and views on the fifth, sixth, and seventh grounds, the afflictive hindrances of the twofold illumination on the eighth, ninth, and tenth grounds, and so forth, up to the afflictive hindrances above the one hundred thousand asaá¹ƒkhyeya practices of the Buddha's fruition. Such afflictive hindrances to practice are immeasurable and boundless.
Disciples!
Today, I sincerely bow to the Buddhas, the honored Dharma, and the noble assembly in the ten directions, feeling ashamed and repenting, wishing for all to be eradicated.
I wish to rely on this repentance to eliminate all afflictive hindrances to practice, leaving no remainder.

May the disciple, wherever he is born, be free from the turning of karmic bonds, and with spiritual powers, in a single thought, reach the ten directions, purify the lands of the buddhas, and transform and guide sentient beings. In the profound realm of meditation and concentration, and in all knowledge and insight, may he penetrate without obstruction, and his mind be able to universally pervade all dharmas, speaking happily without end and without attachment.

May he attain mastery of the mind, mastery of the Dharma, mastery of wisdom, and mastery of skillful means, causing these afflictions and the bonds of ignorance to be forever severed and not continue, and the uncontaminated holy path to be as bright as the sun.
The Sutra of the Questions and Answers of the MahÄyÄna Lotus Treasure on Retribution, Spoken by the Åšramaá¹‡a At that time, Bodhisattva Baodai entered another hell, called the Iron Garment Hell.

The hell was sixteen yojanas long and wide, square in shape. In the hell there were iron saws and chisels, sharp like swords, spread all over the ground, with smoke and flames blazing. The iron clothes burned with fire, and the flames burned brightly as they roamed through the hell.
In the east gate there were eight hundred monks, looking up to the sky, beating their chests and crying out loudly, shouting these words:
What crime have we committed to come and enter here?

They rolled around on the ground and could not move forward.ğŸ”½The horse-headed rakshasa held a three-pronged iron trident in his hand and struck their backs with it, coming out from their chests, their bodies burning all over with fire.
The horse-headed rakshasa held an iron hook in his hand and stabbed their skeletons with it, and when the iron hook touched them, flames arose together.
The sinners rolled around and refused to come, and the horse-headed rakshasa held an iron hammer in his hand and struck their heads with it.

There were also iron dogs that came to eat its flesh, and hungry ghosts that came to drink its blood. In that hell, iron clothes came flying and covered the sinners, either covering their heads or their feet, burning all over their bodies. In one day and night, they experienced immeasurable suffering.
Bao Da asked the Horse-Headed RÄká¹£asa:
Why do these sinful monks suffer such punishments?
The Horse-Headed RÄká¹£asa replied:

These sinful monks received the Buddha's pure precepts but did not guard their dignified conduct. They abandoned the correct Dharma robes and put on secular clothes, not in accordance with the Dharma robes. Because of this evil cause and condition, they fell into this hell.
When Bao Da heard this, he wept and said:ğŸ”½How can monks,
called people who have left the three realms,
not be careful themselves and fall into this evil path?
How can they not be careful and suffer this great pain?
How can they attain peace and security?
Are called liberated people.
Thus spoke Baota, and departed.
